bcl:paragraph.bcl:text:
a person whose relatives residing at the place where the person was last known to
          reside, and who would be likely to hear from the person, have not heard from or of the
          person for at least 3 months last past, and have been unable to ascertain the person's
          whereabouts,

bcl:text:
if the person does not have relatives of the kind described in paragraph (a), a
          person whose

have not heard from or of the person for a period of at least 3 months last past
          and have been unable to ascertain the person's whereabouts, and

bcl:subparagraph.bcl:text:
associates at the place where the person was last known to reside,
            and

relatives with whom until then the person had been in the habit of
            communicating,

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text:
a person who has been missing for a shorter period than 3 months, but who is
          otherwise a missing person within the meaning of paragraph (a) or (b), and who is
          declared by the Supreme Court to be a missing person, on application, accompanied by
          evidence to the satisfaction of the court that there is urgent need of a curator being
          appointed under this Act for the preservation of the estate or the support of the
          dependants of that person.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text:
The Supreme Court may appoint a person to be curator of the property or any part
          of the property of a person if it is satisfied on an application that

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: the person is a missing person within the meaning of this Act,

the missing person owns or is interested in property in British Columbia,
            and

it is expedient that a curator be appointed to manage, preserve, deal with or
            dispose of any or all of the property.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: On the application the court may do one or more of the following:

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: even if notice has not been given to anyone, make an order;
set a date for the hearing of the application;

direct that notice of the application be given to persons it thinks
            expedient;
direct that notice be given personally or by publication.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text:
The court must appoint the public guardian and trustee as curator in all cases
          except if it is proved to the satisfaction of the court that some other fit and proper
          person would be a more desirable curator because of

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text:
the business or personal relationship of the other person to the missing person,
            or

bcl:subsection.bcl:text:
The curator is an officer of the court and subject to its control and
          supervision.

The order appointing a curator may impose terms, as to security or otherwise, and
          restrictions and conditions as the court thinks proper.

In respect of the property of the missing person or the part of it to which the
          appointment applies, and subject to this Act and the terms and restrictions of the
          appointment, a curator has the same powers of dealing with the property as the missing
          person would have if that person were present.

Acts done by the curator after the curator's appointment in respect of the property
          are binding on the missing person and the heirs, personal representatives and assignees of
          the missing person.

The custody and management of the property of a missing person is a
          trust.

bcl:text.#text:
The curator is a trustee within the meaning of sections 88, 89, 91, 96, 98 and 100
          of the  and those sections apply to a curator
          appointed under this Act.

bcl:section.bcl:text:
Except with the prior approval of the Supreme Court, a curator appointed under this
        Act has no power to sell or mortgage any of the property of the missing person to which the
        appointment applies if the value of the portion of the property to be sold or the amount to
        be raised by mortgage exceeds $100.

A curator appointed under this Act must use and dispose of the money coming into the
        curator's hands from the property of the missing person as directed by the Supreme
        Court.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text:
With the approval of the Supreme Court, a curator may sue and be sued in respect
          of the property of the missing person or a portion of it to which the appointment
          applies.

In any action it is not necessary for the curator to prove the continued existence
          or mental capacity of the missing person.

bcl:section.bcl:marginalnote: Removal of curator and appointment of new curator

bcl:subsection.bcl:text:
On the application of any person, the Supreme Court may remove from office a
          curator appointed under this Act, and may appoint any other person to be curator
          instead.

The order appointing a new curator may limit or vary the restrictions already
          imposed or impose new restrictions.

The person removed from office must at once submit to the court a true inventory
          and account of the property which has come into the person's hands or under the person's
          control by reason of the appointment and of the person's dealings with it.

bcl:text.#text:
The court may discharge the retiring curator on the passing of accounts under the
          provisions for the passing of accounts of trustees under the .

bcl:subsection.bcl:text:
The new curator has the same rights and powers as if appointed as the original
          curator.

bcl:section.bcl:text: The Supreme Court may vary an order made by it under this Act.

bcl:section.bcl:marginalnote: Discharge of curator on termination of office

bcl:text.#text:
If the person ceases to be a missing person, or on the issue of a representation
        grant, the Supreme Court, on application to it, and on the accounts of the curator being
        passed in accordance with the provisions for the passing of accounts of trustees under the
          , may discharge the curator appointed under this
        Act in respect of the property of the person.

bcl:section.bcl:marginalnote: Effect of filing order in land title office
bcl:section.bcl:text:
An office copy of the order appointing a curator or other order made under this Act
        is, when filed in any land title office, sufficient evidence to the Registrar of Titles of
        the authority of the curator to deal with the property as mentioned in it.

bcl:section.bcl:marginalnote: Effect of appointment on powers of attorney
bcl:section.bcl:text:
On the appointment of a curator of the property or part of the property of a missing
        person, all authority given by the missing person before the person's disappearance in
        respect of the property or part of it, whether by power of attorney or otherwise, is
        immediately cancelled and void, but nothing in this Act invalidates any act done by any
        person under authority from the missing person up to the time of that person learning of the
        appointment of the curator.
